title: Am I the only one who thinks skillshots aren't necessarily a disadvantage?
body: Like there are so many useful and creative ways to use skillshots that you simply can't do with targeted spells. Check bushes, hit invisible champions, lead targets, zone areas, not to mention how a large chunk of them have longer ranges than targeted skills. I people overestimate how much of a disadvantage a skillshot is. Targeted spells may have reliability, but skillshots have versatility and usually range.

replies.body: I would agree, but the average person has the aim as a stormtrooper.
The average person is in fact silver....
And the average person also has the mobility of Jabba the Hutt. Half the time, you can just put your cursor on top of them. They also just run straight back to tower when the jungler shows up.

I agree on Check Bushes, Hit Invisible Champions, and Range. Leading Targets is you attempting to compensate for it not automatically hitting targets, and Zoning is 50/50 (you tend to mind your distance from champions with point and click damage if you can help it).
There are benefits, but the power of reliability is incredibly strong. Imagine if xerath's fully charged Q was guaranteed to hit every time.
Xerath Q doesn't do additional damage for charging up iirc. It just has longer range.

the power of range is also something massively underlooked

it's really hard to shut out {{champion:81}} from getting last hits since he can always use his q from 1k units away to last hit.
veigar when his q got reworked so it became a skillshot he also became considerably safer since his Q was a farming tool and minions don't attempt to dodge.

and the thing about xerath's fully charged q, is even if it misses, he still had the opportunity to fire it from like 1300+ units away with zero repercussions for missing beyond mana cost. cooldown does not matter because that distance from an enemy doesn't put him in any risk that requires his Q to be off cooldown to defend himself.
Veigar got safer because they improved the range as well.
If it was targeted then it would lose damage and range. You can't just say ''imagine if Ez Q was point and click''
The fact that you said it has to be nerfed to become targeted just proves my point. Lol.
Skillshots are also compensated with more power and more range compared to their targetted counterparts.

Skillshots _aren't_ a disadvantage, they just aren't as _reliable_ as targeted spells. You could consider this a disadvantage, but it's really just a property.

my favorite thing about skillshots is that you can hit someone with a spell as they leave stasis or untargetability, which you can't do with a targeted spell.

I sometimes find it easier to hit skillshots than auto attacking. Being able to just cast a spell in the direction of the enemy rather than clicking directly on them gives a significant advantage in close fights. 

Then you fight against a Kalista and I really start to appreciate auto attacks and targeted abilities, although even clicking on Kalista can be a challenge sometimes.

Well, I can see your point, it's not like it's disbalanced (well... overall.) The only problem I can think of, is how non-skillshot champions, when they get put in the right situation, mean the mechanic of 'dodging' becomes unavailable which is really frustrating. You don't feel like there was anything you could do, or more importantly anything you _can_ do for the next trade. Whereas if a Thresh hook hits you, you feel like you are to blame.

Although I agree with you, they are not better in some scenarios. For example, Warwick having a skillshot Ult. There are probably more scenarios, but I can't think of any atm.

This is unrelated, but I like your username.
{{sticker:slayer-pantheon-thumbs}}
Its a shame tho that reliability is always better ....

My problem is that, at it's core, skillshots are RNG. Hitting skillshots relies on you to prediction your opponent's movements, and predictions, no matter how good, are still educated _guesses_. There's always the possibility of it fucking up due to no fault of your own, and that feels extremely unhealthy in MOBAs, where every little lead matters.
I wish I could see a stat that showed me how many of my attempted skillshots I missed and give me an accuracy %. Would be interesting to see how bad I really am.
If Planet Side is any indication, I have about 5-11% accuracy, depending on the weapon. (>_>)
Since skill shots have a faliure scenario, they are allowed to have greater success scenarios, be that more damage, cc, etc.

It may seem to have no trade offs, especially when fighting an immobile champion. However the range doesn't matter if it's a champion like Kalista, Vayne, Lucian, Yasuo, etc. It doesn't matter what range you have if you can't hit the hyper mobile target. Only Blitzcrank, other hook champions, and Nidalee breaks this rule due to how punishing it is to get hit by their skill shots. Most skill shots can be walked off if the target keeps dodging them. However the very threatening ones puts a lot of pressure on the mobile champion and usually results in death.
Tell that to the people who say there's no disadvantage to ADC AAs.
When they made Ryze's Q a skillshot, the first thing I thought was "so he can finally hit something he doesn't have vision of, nice!"
